III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
1

perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Two youth will leave the agency without permission and go into
the trailer to obtain drugs.
Investigation Interviews
On 7/23/2025 DCWL Consultant 2 made an onsite visit to the
agency. Staff was advised of assigned special investigation and
of allegations.
On 7/25/2025 a telephone call was made to Complainant. A
voicemail message was left requesting a return call. On 8/29/25 a
follow up phone call was made to Complainant. Complainant
denied having any additional concerns.
On 7/25/2025 a telephone call was made to Foster Care Worker
(FCW) 1. A voicemail message was left requesting a return call.
On 8/29/25 a follow up phone call was made to FCW1. FCW1
denied having any concerns with the agency, staff from the
agency or supervision by staff.
On 7/25/2025 and 8/29/25 telephone calls were made to FCW 2.
Voicemail messages were left requesting a return call. To date,
no response has been received.
The following interviews were conducted at Beverly House on
7/25/2025 unless otherwise noted.
Interview was completed with Staff 1. She confirmed that both
Youth A and Youth B have been frequently going AWOL from the
facility. She reported she and other staff have been talking with
the youth advising of the safety and legal concerns of going
AWOL and engaging in inappropriate behavior with other youth in
the neighboring community. Staff 1 stated talks and other attempts
to redirect the youth from going AWOL have not been successful.
Other actions put in place to deter AWOL include scheduling more
structured activities, additional recreation time, offering rewards
for positive behavior and offering to go for walks with the youth if
“cool off” time is needed. Staff 1 reported that all staff are
engaged and making appropriate attempts to deter AWOLs by
Youth A, Youth B and other youth placed in the facility.
2

An interview was completed with Staff 2. She also confirmed that
Youth A and Youth B frequently AWOL into the neighboring
community and usually return on their own within 2 hours or so.
Staff 2 reported law enforcement is contacted and notified when
the youth go AWOL. She indicated attempts to deter AWOL of the
youth have not been successful. She personally reported
engaging in conversation with the youth and advising of safety
concerns related to AWOL.
An interview was completed with Youth A. She stated she had
just returned to the facility today from Wayne County Juvenile
Detention Center for assault of a staff. Youth A was very
escalated and had engaged in damage to the household furniture
right before my arrival. Staff had contacted law enforcement, but
they had not yet arrived. Although she was escalated and
irritated, she agreed to participate in the interview. Youth A
confirmed that she and Youth B often go AWOL and visit with
friends in the neighboring community. She refused to provide
details about who and where they go in the community when they
go AWOL. Youth A also refused to respond to questions about if
she engages in drug use while AWOL. Youth A reported she
“goes AWOL whenever she wants” despite what staff says. She
stated that staff can’t stop her and cannot restrain her just
because she wants to go AWOL. She confirmed that staff will try
to deter youth from going AWOL, but she does not listen and goes
anyway because she should be able to visit her friends. Youth A
stated that other youth have also gone AWOL from the facility but
would not say names of the other youth. Youth A saw Law
Enforcement arrive and stated she wanted to end the interview.
Officers made attempts to talk with Youth A. Initially she was
compliant but became agitated and stated she was going AWOL
again. Staff 1, Staff 2, Law Enforcement officers and myself
attempted to deter Youth A from going AWOL, however she
continued to leave and walked into the neighboring community.
Youth A was again interviewed on 8/5/25 at Beverly House. She
reported that she has not gone AWOL from the facility since
7/25/25. She again confirmed that staff tell her she “shouldn’t go”
AWOL and try to get her to see why it is not safe.
An interview was completed with Youth B. She also confirmed
that she and Youth A go AWOL from Beverly House and visit
“friends” in the neighboring community. She admitted to seeing
others smoke cigarettes and Vape Pens while being AWOL.
Youth B stated that staff are “always” talking with them about not
going AWOL and how it is dangerous. Youth B further stated that
3

staff will sometimes follow or walk with them to a certain spot
while trying to get them to return to the agency, but it is not
successful. Youth B stated she has been making attempts not to
go AWOL and has not left the agency without permission within
the last 7 days. Youth B was unable or unwilling to discuss
reasons why she frequently AWOLs.
An interview was completed with Law Enforcement Officer
(LEO). He arrived at the facility in response to a call by the staff
that Youth A was destroying agency property and would not
respond to redirection by staff. LEO stated that his department
has made 194 runs to Beverly House since January 1, 2025. He
did not have figures on the number that were related to youth
going AWOL. LEO reported that he has always found the staff to
be engaged and responsive to the youth at the facility. He
reported that he has witnessed staff attempt to deter youth from
going AWOL via discussion and redirection. He further denied
any concerns with the supervision provided by Beverly House
staff.
A telephone interview was completed with Supervisor 1. A
request was made for agency AWOL policy, any relevant video
footage and relevant incident reports. Supervisor 1 advised that
she has been engaged with frequent meetings and discussion
with the agency staff brainstorming ideas to deter the youth from
going AWOL. She advised that despite attempts of herself and
other staff, Youth A and Youth B have continued to go AWOL.
She denied any concerns with staff not taking proper action to
make attempts to deter or properly respond to AWOL attempts by
youth. An in-person interview was completed with Supervisor 1
on 8/5/25 at Beverly House. She advised that she has been
encouraging staff to attempt utilization of any of the following to
deter AWOL of youth: Discussion, Offer healthier or safer de-
escalation technique, Engage therapist, Offer incentive after not
AWOLing for 24/48 hours. Supervisor 1 again denied any
concerns relative to the staff providing supervision of the youth
and making attempts to deter youth from going AWOL.
On 08/05/2025 an in-person interview was held with Youth C.
She reported that she has gone AWOL twice since being placed
at Beverly House. She stated that the staff and sometimes other
youth try to talk youth out of going AWOL. Youth C stated that
staff have tried to discuss her feelings with her when she returned
from AWOL and talked with her about how unsafe it is. Youth C
further reported she recalled a meeting was hosted at Beverly
House to discuss youth going AWOL. She reported feeling safe at
4

the agency and reported she feels staff provide adequate
supervision.
On 08/05/25 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 3.
She reported providing proper supervision to youth at the agency
and engaging in attempts to deter or address frequent AWOLs
with youth. Another in-person interview was completed with Staff
3 on 8/26/25 at Beverly House. She reported that AWOLs have
significantly decreased since the discharge of Youth A.
On 08/26/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Youth
D and Youth E at Beverly House. Both youth reported feeling
safe and confirmed that staff provide proper supervision and
redirection for all youth in the facility.
On 8/26/2025 a telephone interview was completed with Chief
Administrator. A follow up request was made for any available
video footage for AWOL incidents between 7/14 and 7/15. She
advised that both her and Supervisor 1 had been working with
their IT department to obtain them.
On 8/28/2025 a telephone interview was completed with Staff 4.
She confirmed being present when Youth A and Youth B have
gone AWOL. She reported working collaboratively with staff to try
to deter the youth from going AWOL. She further reported that
she tries to talk with the youth daily to offer more positive options
for conflict resolution and crisis intervention. She denied seeing
any other staff fail to make attempts to deter youth from AWOLing
or not providing proper supervision of the youth.
On 8/28/25 and 8/29/25 voicemail messages were left for Staff 5
requesting a return call. To date, no response has been received.
Documentation Review
Spectrum Child and Family Services AWOLP Requirements
Policy - Within one business day, the case manager and or
residential manager must notify the program director, DHHS
worker or designee, DCWL of a youth AWOLP status and
interaction with law-enforcement. When notifying DCWL, the
following will be communicated:
• Insight as to what led to the AWOL incident?
• What de-escalation strategies/prevention efforts were
attempted?
• How long was the youth AWOL?
• Provide some feedback as to the plan to prevent future
AWOL incidents for the youth.
5

• Advise of the Agency Assessment of trends or patterns for
the youth.
• Advise of the Agency Assessment of treatment needs for
the youth.
Spectrum Child and Family Services Unusual Incident
Reports – Incidents reports dated 7/12, 7/13, 7/14, 7/15, 7/17,
7/19, 7/20 and 7/24 were reviewed. The reports documented that
Youth A and Youth B went AWOL from the agency. Incident
reports also included documentation of de-escalation steps that
were taken with youth to deter AWOL.
Video Footage
No video footage was made available by the agency. Requests
for video footage was made on 7/25/25, 8/5/25, 8/26/25 and
8/28/25. Chief Administrator responded on 8/29/25 and advised
that the video footage was still not available from the IT
department.
Tour of Agency
A tour of the agency was completed on 7/25/2025 and 8/26/2025.
There were no concerns relative to staff supervision noted at the
time of the agency tour.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance with the licensing rule. Interviews of both staff and
youth were conducted and there was no evidence to support lack
of supervision by the staff resulting in youth going AWOL. Both
youth and staff reported that agency staff make diligent efforts to
discourage youth from going AWOL and engage them in
discussion to advise of dangers associated with going AWOL.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4150 Incident reporting
Section (3) If an institution determines that a youth is absent without legal
Description permission, then the institution shall immediately report the
information to law enforcement, the parent/legal guardian or next
of kin, the licensing authority, and the referring agency.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency failed to notify DCWL of AWOL status of youth.
Investigation Interviews
6

On 07/25/2025 a telephone interview was completed with
Supervisor 1. She confirmed that Youth A and Youth B have
both gone AWOL from the facility on several occasions. She
specifically confirmed the youth went AWOL on 7/12, 7/12, 7/14,
7/15, 7/19, 7/20 and 7/24. She also reported that law enforcement
was contacted and all other AWOL procedures were completed,
including DCWL notification.
Documentation Review
Spectrum Child and Family Services AWOLP Requirements
Policy - Within one business day, the case manager and or
residential manager must notify the program director, DHHS
worker or designee, DCWL of a youth AWOLP status and
interaction with law-enforcement. When notifying DCWL, the
following will be communicated:
• Insight as to what led to the AWOL incident
• What de-escalation strategies/prevention efforts were
attempted
• How long was the youth AWOL
• Provide some feedback as to the plan to prevent future
AWOL incidents for the youth.
• Advise of the Agency Assessment of trends or patterns for
the youth.
• Advise of the Agency Assessment of treatment needs for
the youth.
Spectrum Child and Family Services Unusual Incident
Reports – Incidents reports dated 7/12, 7/13, 7/14, 7/15, 7/17,
7/19, 7/20 and 7/24 were reviewed. The reports documented that
Youth A and Youth B went AWOL from the agency.
Email Notifications from Supervisor sent to DCWL
Consultant: Notification of AWOL status of Youth A and Youth B
was sent via email on 7/12, 7/13, 7/17 and 7/24. There was no
notification of AWOL status sent for 7/14, 7/15 or 7/19.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with the licensing rule. Staff were interviewed,
email correspondences and incident reports were reviewed. The
agency failed to notify DCWL of the AWOL of Youth A and Youth
B for dates of 7/14/25, 7/15/25 and 7/19/25.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
7

Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A Corrective Action Plan is required.
